Award.AwardTitle: CNH-L: Adaptive Coupling of Human Environment Linkages in Response to Globally Driven Changes in Subsistence in Rural Alaska
Award.AbstractNarration:
An active and productive subsistence lifestyle is nutritionally and culturally critical to rural communities in Alaska, yet changes in climate and rising energy costs are challenging rural residents' ability to conduct subsistence activities. Changes in climate will alter ecosystem structure and function, affecting the distribution of subsistence resources and access to the areas where resources are harvested. High fuel costs (e.g., heating, transportation) have forced rural households to make economic sacrifices to maintain and use equipment needed for subsistence. To address these issues, this project will: 1) document specific impacts that environmental change and energy costs are having on subsistence, 2) identify and link characteristics of the human (e.g., policy, household economics) and natural (e.g., climate patterns, landscape change) system that influence vulnerability to impacts, 3) evaluate the effectiveness of current responses to impacts, and 4) enhance communication networks among communities and researchers to foster future adaptation to globally-driven changes. Rather than considering global-change adaptation as a set of discrete actions, this research will treat actions as feedback loops that link social and ecological components at community and regional scales and will test the hypothesis that ineffective adaptation to global change results in part from weak or missing feedbacks. The project involves collaboration with local communities as well as with federal, state, and tribal organizations in Alaska to develop and enhance networks that invent, test, and share adaptations at regional and larger scales. It will enhance capacity to adapt to environmental change in Alaska by engaging community leaders and training graduate students, many of whom are Alaska Natives, in an interdisciplinary research process. Of the 14-member project team, 21% are Alaska Native, 50% are women, and 43% are early-career scholars.

This project will develop a novel framework (adaptive coupling) to study adaptation in social-ecological systems. It will integrates vulnerability and resilience science in a systems context. Rather than considering global-change adaptation as a set of discrete actions, it treats these as feedback loops that link social-ecological components at community and regional scales. The project will test the hypothesis that ineffective adaptation to global change results in part from weak or missing feedbacks from impacts on communities back to the local drivers or factors mediating community sensitivity to these drivers. The investigators seek to understand reasons for weak or missing feedbacks. The research will contribute to theory by integrating qualitative insights from the social sciences (especially related to political ecology and adaptive and collaborative capacities) with more quantitative information from ecology, hydrology, and economics within a systems framework. The dynamics and pathways by which adaptation scales from individual communities to a region will be investigated. In contrast to the literature on top-down diffusion of innovation from agencies to local entities, the investigators will focus on the grassroots emergence of novelty and factors that influence its regional diffusion. The focus on the interface between theory and practical application of knowledge in local communities has the potential to transform the western linear (loading dock) model of science to a more iterative adaptive approach that recognizes the intellectual value of local knowledge and the importance of real-world application as a learning laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project had four major outcomes that contributed to knowledge on how social, economic, and ecological change affect the traditional harvest practices (subsistence hunting, fishing) and the overall well-being of rural communities in Alaska.

First, our project bolstered science engagement and synergy among local, regional, and state interest groups. We completed intensive research partnerships with eight Interior Alaska communities. Each community co-designed and assisted with the implementation of distinct studies that focused on their research priorities for strengthening positive connections between people and the environment. We collaborated with several local and regional Tribal organizations to engage an additional 46 Indigenous communities in survey research on the health of traditional harvest practices. Agencies scientists served as co-investigators to help address project objectives and shape outcomes that informed contentious issues related to resource management and regulations. The extensive interaction with and guidance by our project collaborators resulted in the development of new scientist-community research protocols and frameworks that have now been adopted by University Institutions and other programs in the Arctic. A key outcome from our engagement efforts was a demonstration of the critical importance of devoting sufficient project funds and personnel to maintaining effective communication with rural community participants.    

Our second major outcome was the creation of a set of new community and regional comprehensive databases. For each rural community in Interior Alaska, we compiled a database consisting of 116 variables that included demographic, educational, cultural, economic, ecological, mobility, regulatory, and wild food harvest information. From the holistic database, we identified a subset of community characteristics (Ex. household size, percent of English-only language speakers, public assistance per household) that can be used to track and monitor trends associated with community self-sufficiency and wellbeing. We also generated a regional spatial database that compiled and analyzed maps of subsistence use areas for 40+ communities. Our databases were used to explain variations in land use and harvest patterns over the last 50 years. Our mapping efforts demonstrated that 60% of the land area within Interior Alaska is used by rural communities for subsistence activities. We found that the size of an individual community?s subsistence use area is influenced by population size, subsistence resources harvested, and landscape features (rivers, roads) surrounding each community.

Our third major outcome was a better understanding of how ecological, economic, and social factors influence subsistence activities. We found that climate change is having a disproportionately large impact on access to subsistence resources as compared to the impacts from changes in resource abundance and distribution. Our project generated novel quantitative information on the effects of specific environmental factors (seasonality, hydrology, temperature) on subsistence travel and harvest success rates for important species such as moose and salmon. Through community-based research, we highlighted the association between energy economics and subsistence production. We found that localized renewable energy production, such as wood biomass powerplants, complements subsistence activities. Also, we determined that communities with active and productive subsistence practices are more energy efficient. Our extensive structured surveys of rural community resident?s perspectives revealed that trajectories in the health of traditional harvest practices differ among regions in Alaska, and the best predictors of change in the health of traditional harvest practices are the extent of a household?s ability to participant in subsistence, share and receive harvested foods, and address climate-related challenges. Our findings provided wildlife managers and policymakers with insight into how accounting for climate, energy economics, and cultural factors can help explain variation in the subsistence production and the trajectory of rural community physical and emotional health.

Our fourth major outcome was the spread of innovation in adaptive responses of rural communities to challenges and opportunities generated from rapid social and ecological change. Our findings highlighted the importance of informing large-scale solutions with more localized experiential knowledge and grassroots ideas. Through extensive community input, we revised and enhanced the definition of food security to fit the evolving circumstances of Indigenous groups. Our findings were formative in the development of the Arctic Observing Summit?s Indigenous Peoples Food Security framework. We increased awareness of tools, resources, and approaches for climate adaptation planning and decision-making, and bolstered scientist-rural community networks. We packaged project results to facilitate uptake by broad audiences and application by end-users. With regards to academic and science communities, our project supported 19 graduate and undergraduate students, influenced academic course curriculum, and led or contributed to 49 journal or juried conference papers, 65 conference presentations, 8 book chapters, 7 agency and tribal organization reports, one book, and new websites and information portals.
